name: Cinnamon Pecan Sandies
description: Rich, buttery, and nutty Cinnamon Pecan Sandies are the perfect easy cookie for dipping into a hot mug of cocoa or adding to your holiday cookie platter.

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 325ºF. Line two baking sheets with parchment paper.
recipeInstructions.name: Preheat the oven to 325ºF. Line two baking sheets with parchment paper.

recipeInstructions.text: Add the room temperature butter and powdered sugar to a mixing bowl. Use a hand mixer or stand mixer to beat the two together until light and creamy (start on low speed to prevent spraying powdered sugar, increase to high once the sugar and butter are combined).
recipeInstructions.name: Add the room temperature butter and powdered sugar to a mixing bowl. Use a hand mixer or stand mixer to beat the two together until light and creamy (start on low speed to prevent spraying powdered sugar, increase to high once the sugar and butter are combined).

recipeInstructions.text: Add the vanilla extract, water, and salt and beat until combined.
recipeInstructions.name: Add the vanilla extract, water, and salt and beat until combined.

recipeInstructions.text: Finally, begin to add the flour, beating on low speed, adding 1/2 cup at a time, until all of the flour is incorporated.
recipeInstructions.name: Finally, begin to add the flour, beating on low speed, adding 1/2 cup at a time, until all of the flour is incorporated.

recipeInstructions.text: Finely chop the pecans, then briefly mix them into the cookie dough. Finally, sprinkle the cinnamon over the cookie dough and use your hands to fold the dough onto itself 3-4 times, or just enough to create swirls of cinnamon throughout the dough, but not have it evenly mixed.
recipeInstructions.name: Finely chop the pecans, then briefly mix them into the cookie dough. Finally, sprinkle the cinnamon over the cookie dough and use your hands to fold the dough onto itself 3-4 times, or just enough to create swirls of cinnamon throughout the dough, but not have it evenly mixed.

recipeInstructions.text: Divide and shape the cookie dough into 24 balls, about 2 Tbsp each. Place the shaped dough onto the cookie sheets then use the palm of your hand or the bottom of a glass to press the dough balls into thick discs.
recipeInstructions.name: Divide and shape the cookie dough into 24 balls, about 2 Tbsp each. Place the shaped dough onto the cookie sheets then use the palm of your hand or the bottom of a glass to press the dough balls into thick discs.

recipeInstructions.text: Bake the pecan sandies for 22-25 minutes, or until the cookies are barely golden on the edges. The appearance of the cookies won't change much after baking. Allow the cookies to cool slightly before serving.
recipeInstructions.name: Bake the pecan sandies for 22-25 minutes, or until the cookies are barely golden on the edges. The appearance of the cookies won't change much after baking. Allow the cookies to cool slightly before serving.

review.reviewBody: I usually love there recipes from this site, but these cookies were not good at all. They were very dry, very bland. I was very disappointed. I will not be making these again!
I didn't expect this to be so good. Thanks!
I wanted to love these cookies but was a bit disappointed. The pecan flavor comes through, but they also taste really flour-y. They're all right, but no one in my family will eat them but me.

I've looked at this recipe several times through the years, and this weekend while looking for a small batch not terribly sweet cookie recipe, it was time. So delicious, so easy, and with butter having been on sale lately, relatively inexpensive for a nut based cookie. 

Some people have asked about subs for the pecans. Hickory nuts--not usually commercially available--are pecan's smaller cousins. They can be found in wooded areas in much of the US. With very hard shells, they are a pain to crack, but if you have hickory trees in a local park or wooded area, they are free--and delicious. They taste much like pecans. As children in Iowa, we collected them every fall from trees around our schoolyard, and they're plentiful here in NC. Crack them while watching tv and you will be hard pressed not to eat them all. 

Although I haven't used them in this recipe I often use hazelnuts in recipes--even "pecan" pie--as one of my grandsons is allergic to most tree nuts but can eat hazelnuts and almonds. They have more taste than almonds and are excellent in cookies. I've also tossed the shells in the smoker when smoking meats. Trader Joe's always has them, and they are cheaper than some nuts.

These were delicious! So buttery and cinnamon-y. I got 18 cookies from scooping 2 tablespoons of dough per cookie. I liked them so much that I’m going to make these again for my family Christmas lunch!
Delicious and easy!! Happy with how they turned out.

All I can say to this recipe is YES. I have never had these in this form - only with the powdered sugar coating and shaped round. Either way, these are just the best. Thank you for bringing the sweetness on this one!

Delicious! I added two shakes of nutmeg because it is my favorite fall flavor.

Also for a half cup of the flour I used home-ground whole wheat.

These are goooooood. And, easy and quick to make. My butter was rock hard and I was too impatient to wait for it to get to room temp, so I just "defrosted" it in the microwave for a minute, and thankfully it did not ruin my results. They are somehow both crisp and melt-in-your mouth soft, and just sweet enough to satisfy my dessert craving. 

Also, my guy insisted that he hates this kind of cookie, but after trying one he had to admit these are an exception.

I cooked them for less time so they would come out a little on the chewy and softer side and they worked perfectly!
A great recipe!
These turned out perfectly. Mine never really turned golden so I finally took them out after 30 minutes, but they were fine.

I am almost 50 and have made oodles of cookies, but for some reason, this dough was very sticky and the cookies spread quite a bit.  I don’t think “self-rising” flour would do that (that’s all hubby could get in the store), but not sure what else could’ve caused it since I did not measure anything wrong.  They are still tasty, though—almost more salty than sweet, which I like!
